bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, August 5, 1952

div1.p: Hench is disturbed that plans for the memorial park at Camp Lazear still use Finlay's name in connection with Building No. 1. He requests information regarding newspaper reports about Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, August 5, 1952
div1.opener:
August 5, 1952
Senora Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon
Calle X 254, Vedado
Habana, Cuba
My dear Senora Rodriguez Leon:
div1.p:
You will recall that when I visited Havana in January, you and I discussed
the proposals which were being made regarding the erection of a little
memorial park at old Camp Lazear. This was being done, I believe, largely
through Doctors Andreu and Nogueira. I think that I showed you the tentative
blue prints which the engineering section of the Health Department had as
their plans for the memorial park. The draftsmen were calling it Parque
Lazear and had the little Building No. 1 labelled “Caseta de Finlay.” I
called this to Doctor Nogueira's attention. He assured me that it was just
a mistake as he said “After all, Doctor Hench, these draftsmen aren't
medical historians.” He assured me that Building No. 1 would be properly
named and I was of course hoping that Camp Lazear could retain its name or
perhaps be called Parque Lazear.

However I have been somewhat disturbed as have certain Cuban friends who
have written me about a continuing phraseology used in the newspapers and
I have written Doctor Nogueira urging that he make the appropriate cor-
rections and inform the newspapers and the public before the dedication
ceremonies sometime in September on the occasion of the International
Congress of Hygiene in Havana. I am hoping to hear from Doctor Nogueira
that he is accomplishing these corrections.

Meanwhile, I thought that I would send you the two enclosures. First of all,
I enclose a synopsis of certain dates showing certain of your father's activities
between 1898 and 1902, as given by some of the material I have in my possession
and some of the material that you already have. I promised some months ago to
send you this. If you want additional copies, please let me know. Secondly,
let me send you some of the excerpts from the Habana papers and you will see
what concerns me. Anything you notice in the papers I will be interested in
knowing about. I still have faith in, or want to have faith in, Doctor
Nogueira and believe that they will do the proper thing.
div1.closer:
Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Enclosures
Senora Rodriguez Leon
- 2 -
August 4, 1952
P.S.: Doctor Nogueira asked me recently to send him a correct list of the names
of the U. S. Army Yellow Fever Board and all of the volunteers. In developing
this list I found that many of the names had been spelled various ways and it
was not at all easy to compile a list correct enough to be perpetuated in
bronze.
May I ask you to help me with your father's name? I have almost uniformly
seen it written Aristides Agramonte, with no middle name. But I have in
my possession two letters addressing him as Aristides A. Agramonte. One is
a letter of September 20, 1900 sent to him by H. L. Scott, Adjutant General,
Division of Cuba; the other is a letter of September 22, 1900, sent to your
father by Leonard Wood, Military Governor of Cuba. As I said, both of these
letters address him as Aristides A. Agramonte. Would you kindly let me know
at your earliest convenience whether he did have a middle name which he rarely
used and perhaps if you have the time to do so, you might telephone Dr.
Pedro Nogueira, Marti 219, Havana, (or drop him a short note), giving him your
father's correct name. They may already be starting to make the bronze tablet
and I would not want the name to be incorrect or the middle name to be left
out if he had one.
Perhaps for the moment it might be best for you not to mention to Doctor
Nogueira that I sent you the excerpts from the newspapers. On the other
hand, if you have any way of finding out from him what they plan to do, that
would be fine. Could you innocently ask him when they plan to dedicate the
park? You might mention that I wrote you asking you to confirm to him your
father's middle name (as I have written him). Then you might also innocently
mention that you have been noticing certain articles in the papers which
indicated some confusion in the minds of the newspapers as to what went on
at Camp Lazear and then see what he replies. I am merely trying to give him
every opportunity to make the corrections and do not want to stir up for him
any trouble unless such becomes necessary.
P.S.H.
